list.title: Question 1
list.content:
What is the maximum number of electrons in the $4p$ subshell?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 6
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 10
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 2
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 8
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For $p$, $l$ is equal to 1. The number of electrons in a given subshell can be calculated using the formula:
$2(2\,l + 1) = 2((2)(1) + 1) = 6$ electrons
The $p$ subshell holds 3 orbitals. Each orbital can fit 2 electrons. Therefore, $p$ subshell holds 6 electrons.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
What is the electron configuration of this orbital diagram?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/aebba581-d5ec-4940-850d-7777dc859933/CH0262.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2p^3\,2s^2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^3\,2p^2$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^2\,3s^3$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The orbital diagram shows two electrons in the $1s$ orbital, two in the $2s$ orbital, and three singly placed in the $2p$ orbitals. This adds up to seven electrons, which is the electron count for nitrogen in its ground state. According to the Aufbau principle, the 1s orbital is filled first, followed by $2s,$ and then $2p.$ The Pauli exclusion principle requires that each orbital holds no more than two electrons with opposite spin, and Hund's rule explains why the three $2p$ electrons occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before any pairing occurs.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/566bc402-15c8-4c3e-ad06-0370a9a3d480/CH0262ms.png)

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Which of the following subshells contains the highest energy?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2s$
- B.$\hspace{1em}2p$
- C.$\hspace{1em}2d$
- D.$\hspace{1em}3d$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to Aufbau’s principle, the arrangement of subshell in increasing energy is $1s\  2s\  2p\  3s\  3p\  4s\  3d\  4p$.
Therefore, options A and B are both incorrect.
Option C is incorrect because $2d$ does not exist.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
What is the term for the region where there is the highest probability of finding an electron?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Orbital
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Nucleus
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Orbital diagram
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Orbit
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Choice B is incorrect because electrons are not located in the nucleus. Choice C is incorrect because an orbital diagram is just a representation of electrons in an orbital. Choice D is incorrect because electrons do not have a fixed orbita around the nucleus in the quantum mechanical model. Choice A is the correct answer: orbitals are areas/ regions in space where the probability of finding an electron is very high.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration of a typical sodium ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 2s^1$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number of sodium is 11. Its electron configuration follows the Aufbau principle, filling the electron sublevels from lowest to highest energy.
$\ce{Na}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^1$
This can be rewritten in noble gas or shorthand notation by observing that the noble gas neon has the same core electron filling $(\ce{Ne}:\, 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6)$.  The electron configuration of neutral sodium can be rewritten as
$\ce{Na}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]\,3s^1$
The atom loses one electron to become a stable ion with a charge of 1+ (10 electrons). The removed electron is from the valence shell (the $3s$ electron).  The electron configuration of sodium ion is
$\ce{Na^+}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]$
Alternatively, notice that sodium ion is isoelectronic with neon so mush share its electron configuration.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct orbital diagram for carbon?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/066637b2-f566-4b62-b75f-a0c115e9e333/images/a4cab57f-5217-4efe-af6f-d75f693b583d/2.2-261-a.png)

B.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/066637b2-f566-4b62-b75f-a0c115e9e333/images/3114e4fe-bfa7-4ddc-97ef-56e672a86f06/2.2-261-b.png)

C.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/066637b2-f566-4b62-b75f-a0c115e9e333/images/240ef3de-9983-4b35-aaca-3703afdccbe1/2.2-261-c.png)

D.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/066637b2-f566-4b62-b75f-a0c115e9e333/images/ba43d172-e47c-4858-bd7e-cf2f2dfe27b9/2.2-261-d.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Choice A is incorrect because the orbital diagram does not satisfy Hund's rule wherein all orbitals must be singly occupied before pairing.
Choice B is incorrect because Pauli's Exclusion principle is not obeyed by having two electrons with the same spin in one orbital.
Choice C is correct because, according to Hund's rule, the orbitals must be half-filled first before pairing, and the paired orbital must have electrons in an opposite spin.
Choice D is incorrect because the $2s$ orbital must be filled first before filling the 2p orbital, as illustrated by Aufbau's Principle.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which of the below gives the correct electron configuration of a $\ce{Cr^3+}$ ion?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1 3d^2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^2 3d^1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^3$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^4$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Electron configuration of the $\ce{Cr}$ atom is $\ce{[Ar]\,} 4s^1\,3d^5$.
The loss of one s and two d electrons results in $\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^3$ configuration.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Which statements about the hydrogen emission spectrum are correct?


- I.The lines converge at higher energiesII.The lines converge at higher frequenciesIII.The lines converge at higher wavelengths



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The lines converge as energy levels increase (increased distance from the nucleus).
Higher energies result in higher frequencies.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Which of the following statements about $\ce{^{51}_{23}V}$ are correct?


- I.It has 23 protonsII.It has 51 nucleonsIII.It has a condensed electron configuration of [Ne] $4s^2\,3d^3$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Vanadium has an atomic number of 23 therefore statement I is true. It also has a mass number of 51, therefore statement II is also true as nucleons include both protons and neutrons. Statement III is false as the closest noble gas is Ar, not Ne. The correct condensed electron configuration would be [Ar] $4s^2\,3d^3$. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Hydrogen exhibits two emission lines, $D1$ and $D2$. $D1$ has a wavelength of $656 \textrm{\ nm}$ and $D2$ has a frequency of $6.17\times 10^{14}\textrm{\ s}^{-1}$. - Calculate the frequency of the $D1$ emission line of hydrogen. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of the $D2$ emission line of hydrogen. [1] - Compare the two emission lines, and using the IB Chemistry data booklet, suggest which of the emission lines is most likely to be red. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The frequency of $D1$ emission line of hydrogen:
  $\begin{aligned}
  f &= \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{656 \textrm{\ nm} \times \frac{1\textrm{\ m}}{1 \times 10^9 \textrm{\ nm}}} \\
  f &= \answer{4.57 \times 10^{14} \textrm{ s}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \textrm{Rearranging the formula:}\ c &= \lambda f, \\
  \textrm{We obtain:}\  f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The wavelength of the $D2$ emission line of hydrogen:
  $\begin{aligned}
  \lambda &=\dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{6.17 \times 10^{14} \textrm{\ s}^{-1}}  \\
  \lambda &= 4.86\times 10^{-7} \textrm{\ m} \times \dfrac{1\textrm{\ m}}{1 \times 10^9 \textrm{\ nm}} = \answer{486 \textrm{\ nm}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \textrm{Rearranging the formula:}\ c &= \lambda f, \\
  \textrm{We\ obtain:}\ \lambda &=\dfrac{c}{f}  \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The frequency $D2 > D1$ and the wavelength $D1 > D2$; $\checkmark$
  $D1$ with the larger wavelength and smaller frequency is more likely to be on the red end of the visible spectrum. $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
What will happen to the frequency of moving light particles if the wavelength is doubled, assuming the velocity is constant?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will be doubled
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will decrease by half
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will not be affected
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency will increase by four
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
There is an inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength. If the wavelength is doubled, the frequency will decrease by half. Therefore, Choices A, C, and D are all incorrect.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?


- I.The emission spectra are produced from a release of energy of excited electronsII.No two electrons in one atom have the same set of quantum numbersIII.The electrons in an orbital must have an opposite spin



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement I is true because emission spectra are produced when photons are released from excited electrons returning to lower energy levels.
Statement II is true because this is Pauli's Exclusion principle.
Statement III is also true because it is included in Pauli's Exclusion principle.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Mass spectrometry uses fast-moving electrons to ionize particles and determine the mass-to-charge ratio of an unknown compound. - Using the data booklet section 1 and 2, calculate the frequency of an electron with a wavelength of 1.68 m. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of an electron with a frequency of $2.00\times 10^8\,\text{s}^{-1}$. [1] - State the effect of increasing the wavelength on frequency. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $f = \dfrac{c}{\lambda} = \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8 \,\text{m s}^{-1}}{1.68\,\text{m}} = \answer{1.79\times 10^8\,\text{s}^{-1}}\,\checkmark$
- $\lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{2.00\times 10^8\,\text{s}^{-1}} = \answer{1.50\,\text{m}}\,\checkmark$
- As you increase the wavelength, you decrease the value of the frequency. Therefore, the frequency is inversely proportional to the wavelength. $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Which of the following correctly compares the $2s$ and $3s$ atomic orbitals?


- Average distance from the nucleusOrbital energyA.$\hspace{1em}$ $2s > 3s$ $2s < 3s$B.$2s > 3s$ $2s > 3s$C.$2s < 3s$ $2s < 3s$D.$2s < 3s$ $2s > 3s$
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The $3s$ orbital is larger than the $2s$ orbital so an electron in a $3s$ orbital is, on average, farther from the nucleus than one in a $2s$ orbital. Additionally, the $3s$ orbital is higher in energy because electrons in higher energy levels experience weaker electrostatic attraction to the nucleus, due to increased shielding by inner electrons and greater average distance. Therefore, both the average distance and the energy of the $3s$ orbital are greater than those of the $2s$ orbital.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Deuterium is an isotope of hydrogen that contains one proton, one neutron, and one electron. - - Complete the following table. [2] - ProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative chargeRelative mass$\sim\dfrac{1}{1836}$Location $\\$ - Using the following data, calculate the relative atomic mass of hydrogen correct to five decimal places, showing your work. [2] - IsotopeRelative abundanceHydrogen-199.980%Deuterium0.012%Hydrogen-30.008% $\\$ - - Describe the emission spectrum of the hydrogen atom. [2] - Outline the difference between a continuous spectrum and a line spectrum. [1] - Suggest how your answer to (b)(i) shows that energy levels are quantized. [1]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - All correct, two $\checkmark$
    Allow one $\checkmark$  for one correct
    
    
    - ProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative charge+10$-1$Relative mass11$\sim \dfrac{1}{1836}$LocationNucleusNucleusOutside the nucleus
      $\\$

  - $\dfrac{99.980}{100} \times 1 + \dfrac{0.012}{100} \times 2 + \dfrac{0.008}{100} \times 3 = 1.00028$
    Correct working $\checkmark$
Correct answer $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    To calculate the relative atomic mass, we need to multiply the isotopic masses with their relative abundances and add them together.

- 
  - A series of lines $\checkmark$ that converge at higher energies. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The hydrogen emission spectrum has a series of lines that get closer together at one end. These lines represent wavelengths of light that are emitted when an electron jumps between energy levels. As electrons move further from the nucleus, the energy levels become closer in energy so the energy difference decreases and the lines are closer together and converge.
  - In a continuous spectrum, all wavelengths are possible. In a line spectrum, only certain wavelengths are possible. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    In the hydrogen emission spectrum, only certain wavelengths of light equal to the energy difference between two energy levels are possible, forming a line spectrum. A continuous spectrum is not restricted to certain wavelengths, rather all wavelengths are possible.
  - Since the lines are discrete and represent electron jumps between energy levels, this shows us that the energy levels are quantized. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The hydrogen emission spectrum is a line spectrum that only contains certain wavelengths of light. The lines represent an electron releasing energy as it drops to a lower energy level, equal to the energy difference between the two energy levels. In order for the lines to be discrete, the conclusion must be made that energy levels are quantized.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope of the element cobalt that is used to treat thyroid cancer. - - State the full electron configuration of cobalt and chromium. [2] - Explain what is special about the electron configuration of chromium. [1] - State the atomic symbol notation for the cobalt-60 isotope. [1] One atom of cobalt-60 undergoes beta decay, releasing an electron and energy with a frequency of $7.65\times 10^{19}$ Hz to form nickel-60. - - Using section 1 of the data booklet, calculate the wavelength of energy released from beta decay. [1] - Using section 3 (Section 5- 2025 Syllabus) of the data booklet and your answer to (b) (i), deduce the type of electromagnetic radiation emitted. [1] - - Define orbital. [1] - Sketch the shapes of an s-orbital and a p-orbital. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Co: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. $\checkmark$
    Cr: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^5$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    We first need the number of electrons in the element which can be found from its atomic number. Orbitals are filled from lowest energy to highest energy - $1s,\,2s,\,2p,\,3s,\,3p,\,4s,\,3d$. Remembering that there are $1s$ orbital, $3p$ orbitals and $5d$ orbitals, with each orbital housing at most two electrons, we can write the electron configuration of cobalt. Chromium is an exception to filling the $4s$ orbital before the $3d$ orbitals and instead is $4s^13d^5$ instead of $4s^2\,3d^4$.
  - Based on the elements preceding chromium, we would expect chromium to have an electron configuration of $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^4$ but instead it is $1s^2\,2s^22p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^5$ due to the relative energies of the $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Hund's rule states that degenerate orbitals should be first singly filled before pairing electrons up but due to the relative energies of the $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals, the $4s^1\,3d^5$ configuration of chromium is possible and more stable than the $4s^2\,3d^4$ so it is favoured.
  - $\ce{^{60}_{27}Co}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    The atomic number is the bottom number which can be found using the periodic table and the mass number which is given in the question is the top number. Co is the atomic symbol for cobalt.

- 
  - $c = f\lambda \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3\times 10^8}{7.65\times 10^{19}} = \answer{3.92\times 10^{-12}\text{m}}\,\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Using the data booklet, we can find the relevant equation  $c = f\lambda$. Next, we need to rearrange the equation to make wavelength the subject. Then, we substitute the frequency from the question and the speed of light constant from the data booklet to calculate the wavelength in meters.
  - Gamma rays. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    Using the data booklet, we can see that $10^{-12}$ m lies in the region of gamma rays.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Each element contains a different arrangement of electrons, and these electron configurations can also be represented using orbital diagrams. Determine the identity of each element described below. - $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1$ [1] - $\ce{[Ne] }3s^2\,3p^6$ [1] - In Period 3 with valence electrons of 3$s^2$ [1] - An element with electron configuration ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28b09a53-c289-460a-8566-78a2419e5fac/images/833703a9-e874-4501-9424-4af7dad37294/ch0263d-new.png) [1] - An ion with 1+ charge, with valence electrons of![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28b09a53-c289-460a-8566-78a2419e5fac/images/28088b14-f7f5-479b-ad6a-5c2480eb22b2/ch0263e-new.png) [1]
list.markScheme:
- $\ce{Potassium (K)}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: number of electrons $\,= 19$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 19 \rightarrow \text{Potassium}$
  Method 2: $4s^1$ shows that element is in group 1 and period 4 $\rightarrow$ Potassium
- $\ce{Argon (Ar)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: group 18 (8 valence electrons) and period 3 (n = 3) $\rightarrow$ Argon
  Method 2: number of electrons$\,= 18$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 18 \rightarrow \text{Argon}$
- $\ce{Magnesium (Mg)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: period 3 and group 2 ( 2 valence electrons on 3s$^2$) → Magnesium.
  Method 2: Electron configuration should be 1$s^2 2$s^2 2$p^6$ 3$s^2$. A total of 12 electrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z =$ number of protons = 12 → Magnesium
- $\ce{ Fluorine (F) }$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: number of electrons $= 9$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 9 \rightarrow \text{Fluorine}$
  Method 2: period 2 (n = 2) and group 17 (7 valence electrons) $\rightarrow$ Fluorine
- $\ce{Sodium (Na)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: Electron configuration of the ion: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6$
  Electron configuration of the atom: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1$
  n = 3 (period 3) and 1 valence electron (group 1) $\rightarrow$ Sodium.
  Method 2: Electron configuration of the ion: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6$
  Electron configuration of the atom: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1$.
  A total of 11 electrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z$ = number of protons = 11 $\rightarrow$ Sodium

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
In an atom with many electrons, which set of orbitals is arranged in order of lowest electron energy to highest electron energy?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2p, 3d, 4s, 4p$
- B.$\hspace{1em}4s, 2p, 4p, 3d$
- C.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 3d, 4p$
- D.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 4p, 3d$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electrons fill sublevels according to the Aufbau Principle shown below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c0a4e08-133c-402d-8e75-db2d84192445/images/cbfc092e-d8aa-4e64-9b84-a94c1674e5b6/CH0775.png)


Following this order, $2p < 4s < 3d < 4p$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
Which electron configuration represents the most stable magnesium ion?


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^1$
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The electron configuration of an ion can be determined by first identifying the electron configuration of the neutral atom. The electron configuration for the magnesium atom is:
Mg: $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2$
When magnesium forms an ion, it loses two electrons from its outermost orbital as it is in Group 2. The electron configuration for the magnesium ion is
$\ce{Mg^2+}:\ 1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6$

list.title: Question 22
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ and $\ce{Cu+}$ have the following electron configurations:
$\ce{Cu}:\quad 1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,3d^{10}$
$\ce{Cu+}:\quad 1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^{10}$
The valence electron lost in the $\ce{Cu+}$ ion is the electron in the $4s$ sublevel.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Which of the following elements has more electrons in the third energy level than in the second?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Potassium
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Calcium
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Scandium
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sulfur
list.markScheme:
C

$\textbf{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Consider the electron configuration of each atom.  Using the Aufbau principle, and placing the electrons in order of increasing energy, we find:
ElementElectron Configuration$\quad \mathbf{n=2} \quad$ $\quad \mathbf{n=3} \quad$S$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^4$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$ $\ce{6 e⁻}$K$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^1$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$Ca$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$Sc$1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^1$ $\ce{8 e⁻}$ $\ce{9 e⁻}$
Only scandium has more electrons in the $n=3$ level, due to placing an electron in the $3d\text{-}$sublevel.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Which of the following pairs of terms describe the shape of an $s-$orbital and the relative energy of a $d-$orbital?


- $\enskip\textbf{Shape of \textit{s--}orbital}\enskip$ $\enskip \textbf{Relative energy of \textit{d--}orbital}\enskip$ $\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$SphericalLow$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$Dumbbell$-$shapeHigh$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$SphericalHigh$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$Dumbbell$-$shapeLow
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The $s-$orbital has a spherical shape. In terms of energy, $s$ has the lowest, followed by $p$ and $d-$orbitals. Thus, Choices A, B, and D are all incorrect.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: Manganese presents a variety of oxidation states. - Deduce the number of electrons in $\ce{Mn^2+}.$ [1] - Annotate the diagram below showing $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals for $\ce{Mn^2+}$ using an arrow to represent the electron. [1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/5187fdb0-7f67-4f43-8bea-03f13ed342a2/unnamed%20(20).png) - Deduce the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Mn^7+}.$ [1]
list.markScheme:
- 23 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 2 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ has 23 electrons.
- $\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$
  $\ \ \ \  \ $![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/beef272b-28c3-4a37-8177-6591746d64ea/unnamed%20(21).png)

$\checkmark$
  Do not penalize the omission of the $4s$ orbital.
- $\ce{[Ar]}$ OR $\ce{[Ne]}3s^2\,3p^6\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 7 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^7+}$ has 18 electrons. If we apply the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle, its electronic configuration turns out to be $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6.$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
Which species have the same electron configuration?


- I.Ni, Cu$^+$, Zn$^{2+}$II.$^{12}$C, $^{13}$C, $^{14}$CIII.O$^{2-}$, F$^-$, Ne



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement II is correct as isotopes only differ in the number of neutrons.
Statement III is correct as they are all isoelectronic with Ne (full valence shell).
At first glance, Statement I may look correct as they all have the same number of electrons. However, since they are transition metals, we must consider how the electrons are arranged in the  $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals.
Ni has an electron configuration of [Ar] $4s^2\,3d^8$ whereas Cu$^+$ and Zn$^{2+}$ have electron configurations of [Ar] $3d^{10}$, remembering that copper is an exception and that $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons in ions.  Statement I is incorrect.

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Which atoms' orbital diagram does this figure represent?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f476c2e5-1379-4cbc-9583-33c80808e480/images/5ddeef50-9182-4ed9-8ebe-f191c34ff22a/2.2-260.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{C}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{O}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{N}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{F}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The number of arrows denotes the number of electrons the atom has. The orbital diagram shown here has 8 arrows which tells you that there are 8 electrons.
Choice A  is not correct because C has only 6 electrons.
Choice D is also not correct because F has 9 electrons.
Choice C is incorrect as N has 7 electrons.
Among the choices, oxygen in its neutral form has 8 electrons. Hence, choice B is the correct answer.

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
Which of the following represents the correct ground state electron configuration of chromium?


- A.$\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^4\,4s^2$
- B.$\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,4d^4$
- C.$\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^1$
- D.$\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,4d^5$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The electron configuration of chromium (Cr) is unusual because it violates the aufbau principle, which states that electrons will fill orbitals in order of increasing energy.
Normally, the $4s$ orbital would be completely filled before the $3d$ orbital, since the $4s$ orbital has a lower energy level than the $3d$ orbital.
The electron configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^1$ is more stable because it maximizes the number of half$-$filled and completely filled $d$ orbitals, which are energetically favorable. Half$-$filled and completely filled $d$ orbitals are more stable than partially filled $d$ orbitals, due to electron$-$electron repulsion effects.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Which of the following species has the highest number of unpaired electrons?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{2+}}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{3+}}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{6+}}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Chromium is one of the exceptions to completely filling the 4$s$ orbital before the 3$d$ orbital.
It has an electron configuration of $[Ar] 4s^1  3d^5$ and all six valence electrons are unpaired. As electrons are removed to form chromium ions, the number of unpaired electrons decreases. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 30
list.content: $\ce{^{63}Cu}$ and $\ce{^{65}Cu}$ are the two most abundant isotopes of copper. - - Define isotope. [1] - Determine the correct numbers of subatomic particles to complete the following table. [1] - Copper-63Copper-65Number of protonsNumber of electronsNumber of neutrons - Calculate the relative abundances of $\ce{^{63}Cu}$ and $\ce{^{65}Cu}$ using section 6 (Section 7- 2025 Syllabus) of the data booklet. [3] - Complete the orbital diagram for the valence electrons in a copper atom and a copper (II) ion. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/f470055e-fefe-474a-8407-420630894d44/CH0684b.png)
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Isotopes of an element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers / same number of protons but a different number of neutrons. $\checkmark$
  - All correct $\checkmark$
    
    
    - Copper-63Copper-65Number of protons2929Number of electrons2929Number of neutrons3436

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The number of protons for both isotopes is the same as the atomic number of copper. Since both isotopes are electrically neutral, the number of electrons is the same as the number of protons. The number of neutrons is calculated by subtracting the number of protons from the mass number.
  - Let $x$ be the relative abundance of copper-63. Using the data booklet, the relative atomic mass of copper is 63.55.
    $\dfrac{63x+65\left(100-x\right)}{100} = 63.55\quad \Longrightarrow \quad -2x = -145\,\checkmark$
    Relative abundance of copper-63: $x=72.5\%$ $\checkmark$
    Relative abundance of copper-65: $100-x=100-72.5=27.5\%$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The relative atomic mass is calculated by finding the weighted average of the isotopes. This means we can find the relative abundances if we know the relative atomic mass of copper and the isotopes of copper.
    We know that the relative abundances of the two isotopes must add up to 100$\%$ so we can set the abundance of copper-63 as a variable $x$ and the abundance of copper-65 as $100-x$. We can set up an equation with these abundances and the isotopic masses and rearrange to solve for $x$. With $x$, we can then calculate the individual abundances.

- All arrow correct for each of Cu and Cu$^{2+}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/c82d90ce-ffac-4589-bfed-d237efe0d33e/CH0684b-MS.png)


  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Copper is one of the exceptions to having the 4s orbital completely filled before filling the 3d orbital $-$ it has an electron configuration of [Ar] $4s^1\,3d^{10}$. When removing electrons to form cations, the 4s electrons are removed before the 3d electrons so the copper (II) ion has an electron configuration of  [Ar] $3d^9$. When drawing the orbital diagrams, remember that each orbital can only fit two electrons of opposite spin and each degenerate 3d orbital is first singly filled before pairing the electrons up.

list.title: Question 31
list.content: $\ce{Cu}$ is a transition metal commonly used in wires. - Determine the complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$. [1] - State the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Cu+}.$ [1] - Determine whether the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ follows the usual rules of electron configuration. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Longhand/complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$
  $\ce{1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^{10} 4s^1}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\ce{Cu}$ is one of the exceptions where a $3d$ orbital would fill before $4s$ and this is due to the fact that a full $3d$ orbital is more stable.
- Condensed electron configuration
  $\ce{[Ar]\,3d^{10}}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  1 electron lost from $4s$ orbital (highest energy level).
- There is an anomaly with the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ simply because there is slightly greater stability associated with the fully filled ($3d^{10}$) subshell than the incomplete one. Hence, the $3d^{10}$ is filled first before pairing the $4s$ subshell. $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are present in a ground$\text{--}$state arsenic (As) atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$6
- D. $\hspace{1em}$7
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filled $p$ subshells, or 6 filled $p$ orbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is  $[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.$ Hund's rule reminds us that the three valence $p$ electrons in arsenic will singly$\text{--}$occupy the three $4p$ orbitals. There will be 6 fully occupied $p$ orbitals.

$\checkmark$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Which is not a possible orbital-box diagram?


- $\hspace{0.9em}$ $\textrm{A.}$ $\hspace{0.em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/78b9add3-0086-4d1a-98d1-fbf9a07a22ff/2-681a.png)

B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/0e485853-372a-4b6c-bffe-116908ba27e3/2-681b.png)

C.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/1a0a2d5c-896c-4443-8a01-3b5e55f7d3ac/2-681c.png)

D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/020bc511-da0e-46d9-a097-f28de93e7d96/2-681d.png)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Orbital diagrams must follow three rules: the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle.
Options A and C are the orbital diagrams for copper and chromium respectively $-$ the two exceptions to completely filling the $4s$ orbital before the $3d$ orbital.
Option B is the orbital diagram for either the copper(I) ion or the zinc (II) ion as $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons.
This leaves Option D as the option that is not possible as it is what we would expect the orbital diagram to be for copper if it followed the trend that $4s$ orbitals are filled before $3d$ orbitals. As $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons, this cannot be the orbital diagram for any ions either. A full $3d$ subshell is more stable.

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
An element has the electron configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. Which of the below gives this element the correct number of energy levels, block, and group?


- Energy levelsBlockGroupA.$\hspace{1em}$3$s$2B.$\hspace{1em}$3$d$7C.$\hspace{1em}$4$s$7D.$\hspace{1em}$4$d$9
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This highest principal energy level is 4 ($4s^2$).
The subshell being filled is $3d$, making it a $d-$block element. Its position in the $d-$block and the total number of valence electrons, being 9 ($4s^2 + 3d^7$), places this element in group 9.

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Al$^+$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Zn
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ca
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sc$^{3+}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electron configuration of Al$^+$: [Ne] $3s^2$
Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^{10}$
Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar] $4s^2$
Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^1$.
Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc$^{3+}$ ($1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6$).

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are there in selenium, Se, atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$7
- D. $\hspace{1em}$9
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Selenium's electron configuration is $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^{10}\,4p^4$.
The three $2p$ and three $3p$ orbitals are fully occupied, along with one $4p$ orbital.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89bd9bcb-c836-45ae-92f4-7c208e7e6ff5/images/116855d7-2a12-459d-ac3b-c43a03ebefb5/image.png)

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
Which of the following statements about $p$ orbitals are correct?


- I.A $2p$ orbital has the same shape as a $3p$ orbital.II.Electrons in the $2p$ orbital are, on average, closer to the nucleus than electrons in the $3p$ orbital.III.The angle between the $p_x$ and $p_y$ orbitals is $90^\circ.$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
All $p$ orbitals share the same fundamental dumbbell shape, regardless of their energy level. A $2p$ and a $3p$ orbital have identical shapes but differ in size and energy: the $3p$ orbital is larger and has higher energy. Statement I is correct.
While $2p$ and $3p$ orbitals belong to different energy levels, electrons in a $2p$ orbital are, on average, found closer to the nucleus than those in a $3p$ orbital. This is because as the energy level increases, the average distance between the electron and the nucleus increases as well.  Statement II is also correct.
Finally, the three $p$ orbitals $(p_x, p_y,\text{ and } p_z)$ are oriented along mutually perpendicular axes in three$-$dimensional space. The angle between any two of them, such as $p_x$ and $p_y,$ is $90^\circ.$ Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
Which electrons are lost in the formation of a copper (II)  ion from a copper atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$One $3s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- B. $\hspace{1em}$One $4s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Two $4s$ electrons
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Two $3d$ electrons
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ has the electron configuration $\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1\,3d^{10}$ (a full d-subshell is more stable). The $4s$ electron is lost in the first ionization followed by a $3d$ electron.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
How many unpaired electrons are in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$3
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1
- D.$\hspace{1em}$2
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configuration
Mn: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^5$
according to the aufbau principle.  When transition metals lose electrons, they lose them from the sublevel with the highest $n-$level.  For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the $4s$ sublevel to form the ion $\ce{Mn^2+}$.
$\ce{Mn^{2+}}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^5$
To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e265c959-7bc9-4194-ba46-8554199f8bb3/images/9a9bc6c8-e8b3-49c5-af73-68b3320ed6a3/CH0777.png)


There are five unpaired electrons in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion.

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration for iron in $\ce{FeCl2}?$


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^4$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\  3d^6$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^8$
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The ground$\text{--}$state electron configuration of neutral iron is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6.$ In $\ce{FeCl2},$ iron has a $2+$ charge so two electrons are removed from the iron atom. In transition metals, electrons are removed from the $4s$ sublevel first, not $3d,$ even though $4s$ is filled before $3d.$
Therefore, $\ce{Fe^2+}$ has the configuration $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 3d^6.$

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
Which gives the correct electron configuration for the chromium atom, Cr, and the chromium cation, $\ce{Cr+}$?


- CrCr$\mathbf{^+}$A.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$B.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$C.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^3 4s^2$D.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^5$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Chromium is an exception to the rule for the first$-$row $d-$block elements due to the stability of a half$-$filled $d-$subshell. When forming a positive ion, electrons are first lost from $4s$ and then $3d$.

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.
Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

list.title: Question 44
list.content: Magnesium is a combustible metal that is used in fireworks. - State the electron configuration for magnesium metal atom. [1] - When magnesium is exposed to hydrogen gas, it forms magnesium hydride. State the chemical formula for magnesium hydride and the oxidation state of each element in this compound. [2] Chemical formula: ________ Oxidation state of magnesium: ________ Oxidation state of hydrogen: ________ - Magnesium can be found in magnesium hydroxide, $\ce{Mg(OH)2}.$ State the type(s) of bonds present in magnesium hydroxide. [1] - Deduce the balanced chemical equation, including state symbols, for the combustion of magnesium metal. [1] - If $2.1\,\text{g}$ of magnesium and $1.5\,\text{dm}^3$ of $\ce{O2}$ were combusted at STP, calculate the mass of product formed. [3] - Magnesium reacts with hydrochloric acid, HCl, according to the following equation: $\ce{Mg(s) + 2 HCl(aq) <=> MgCl2(aq) + H2(g)}$ Calculate the molar enthalpy of reaction in $\text{kJ mol}^{-1}$ for Mg if $0.62\,\text{g}$ of Mg reacts with $120.0\,\text{g}$ of $0.8\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl, resulting in a change of temperature from $21.0\,{}^\circ \text{C}$ to $39.8\,{}^\circ \text{C}$ in a calorimeter. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Magnesium is in the $s$ block of the periodic table. Therefore, its valence shell is a set of $s$ orbitals. Since magnesium is in the third row of the periodic table, its outermost orbital is a $3s$, resulting in the electron configuration of $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2$.
- Chemical formula: MgH$_2$ 
Oxidation state of magnesium: +2 $\checkmark$ 
Oxidation state of hydrogen: $-$1 $\checkmark$
Award M1 for 1 correct answer and M2 for 3 correct answers; 
Do not accept 2+ and 1$-$ for the oxidation states.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Metals have low electronegativity and will always have a positive charge in compounds.
  Hydrogen atoms will always have a +1 oxidation state unless bonded as hydride, in which case, hydrogen will have a $-1$ oxidation state.
  The chemical formula for magnesium hydride is determined by using the common charge for magnesium $(+2),$ requiring two hydrogen atoms with a $-1$ oxidation state to balance out the overall charge on the compound.
- ionic and (polar) covalent $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Magnesium ion and hydroxide ion are bonded ionically due to the electrostatic attraction of opposite charges $(\ce{Mg^{2+}}$ and $\ce{OH^-}).$
  The $\ce{O-H}$ bond is covalent within hydroxide due to the closer similarity in electronegativity in the bonded atoms. This bond would be considered polar covalent since oxygen is much more electronegative than hydrogen.
- 2 Mg(s)  +  O$_2$(g) $\longrightarrow$ 2 MgO(s) $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
In a combustion reaction, the material being combusted is combined with oxygen. In this case, the magnesium reacts with oxygen gas in a synthesis reaction, forming magnesium oxide (MgO).
- Mg is the limiting reagent $\checkmark$ 
0.086 mol MgO $\checkmark$ 
3.5 g MgO $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Since the quantities of both reactants are provided in this question, the limiting reagent must be determined as this will dictate the quantity of product:
  $n_{\text{O}_2} = 1.5\,\text{dm}^3 \times \dfrac{1\,\text{mol}}{22.7\,\text{dm}^3} = 0.066\,\text{mol}$ $n_\ce{Mg} = 2.1 \textrm{\ g} \times \dfrac {1\textrm{\ mol}}{24.31 \textrm{\ g}} = 0.086\textrm{\ mol}$
  If O$_2$ is the limiting reagent, then it would need to react with $0.066\textrm{\ mol} \ce{\ O_2} \times \dfrac {2\textrm{\ mol Mg}}{1\textrm{\ mol\ } \ce{O}_2} = 0.132 \textrm{\ mol Mg}$
  Since there is only 0.086 mol of Mg present, $\ce{O_2}$ cannot be the limiting reactant. Therefore, Mg is the limiting reactant, so we use stoichiometry to convert the 0.086 mol Mg into the moles of MgO formed:
  $n_\ce{MgO} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol\ Mg} \times \dfrac {2 \textrm{\ mol Mg}}{2 \textrm{\ mol\ } \ce{MgO}} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol MgO}$ $m_\ce{MgO} = 0.086 \textrm{\ mol MgO} \times \dfrac{40.31 \textrm{\  g}}{1 \textrm{\ mol}} = 3.5 \textrm{\ g MgO}$
- $q_{solution} = 9.43 \textrm{\ kJ} \: \checkmark$ 
$\Delta H = -370 \textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1} \: \checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
This is a calorimetry question that requires the use of the formulas:
  $q_{solution} = mc\Delta T$
$q_{reaction}= -q_{solution}$
$\Delta H = \dfrac {q_{reaction}}{n}$
  where $q_{solution}$ is the heat absorbed by the solution as measured by the thermometer, $q_{reaction}$ is the heat lost during the exothermic chemical reaction, $c$ is the specific heat capacity of the solution, $m$ is the mass of the solution and $\Delta T$ is the change in temperature.
  Importantly, the student must assume that $0.8 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl has a specific heat capacity equal to that of water since it is aqueous $(4.18 \textrm{\ J g}^{-1}\textrm{\ K}^{-1}).$
  Also essential to answering this question, is that the mass is equal only to that of the HCl solution and does not include the mass of magnesium (essentially because the temperature change is being measured in the solution, not on the metal):
  $q_{solution} = 120.0\textrm{\  g} \times 4.18 \textrm{\ J g}^{-1} {^\circ} \textrm{C}^{-1}\times(39.8 - 21.0){^\circ}\textrm{C} = 9430.08 \textrm{\ J}$ 
$q_{reaction} = -9430.08 \textrm{\ J} \Rightarrow -9.43 \textrm{\ kJ}$
  To find the enthalpy change of the reaction, first determine the moles that reacted:
  $n_{Mg} = 0.620 \textrm{\ g Mg} \times \dfrac{1 \textrm{\ mol Mg}}{24.31 \textrm{\ g Mg}} = 0.0255 \textrm{\ mol}$
  Then the enthalpy changes is
  $\Delta H = \dfrac{-9.43 \textrm{\ kJ}}{0.0255 \textrm{\ mol}} = -370 \textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1}$
  $\ $

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
Which statement(s) is(are) correct for chromium?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$The electron configuration for its divalent cation is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^5.$
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$It belongs to the $d-$block.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Its condensed electronic configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}4s^2\,3d^4.$



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$III only
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Neutral chromium has the observed ground$-$state configuration $\ce{[Ar]}4s^1 \,3d^5$ (the $4s$ and $3d$ subshells are very close in energy, and the $4s^1 \,3d^5$
arrangement is lower in energy than $4s^2 \, 3d^4$ for the atom). Statement III is false.
When chromium cations form, the $4s$ electrons are removed before the $3d$ electrons (electrons are removed from the highest $n$ level). For $\ce{Cr^{2+}},$ the electron configuration is $\ce{[Ar]}3d^4.$ Statement I is false.
With its highest$-$energy electrons in the $3d$ subshell, chromium belongs to the $d-$block transition metals.  Its placement in the periodic table supports this assessment.  Statement II is true.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3984ad5b-c9b4-4c1f-b0cd-bb001f4e6c5c/images/661f93f8-2ee6-44fe-9c0f-89c979cd5c80/CH1222.png)

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
The figure shows the visible line emission spectrum of hydrogen.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/3c917e33-7871-4db3-92fb-7ba883f0f5f8/CH2146.png)


Which of the following transitions is most likely responsible for the red line in the spectrum?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n = 5\longrightarrow n = 2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n = 2\longrightarrow n = 1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n = 4\longrightarrow n = 2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n = 3\longrightarrow n = 2$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The red line marked in the figure is the longest-wavelength of the four visible lines and must come from the smallest energy drop that ends at the second energy level. Of the options given, the transition from $n = 3$ down to $n = 2$ fits that description: it releases less energy than drops from $n = 4$ or $n = 5$ to $n = 2,$ so its photon has a longer wavelength and appears red. The $n = 2 \longrightarrow n = 1$ transition is ruled out because it ends at the first level and produces ultraviolet light, which is not visible in the spectrum shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/058442e4-9a9f-423c-b942-81f41aad4b2c/CH2146ans.JPEG)

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
Which of the following statements about electron spin is correct?


- I.Unpaired electrons occupy separate orbitals within a sublevel before pairing occurs.II.Two electrons in the same orbital must have parallel spins.III.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows two electrons to occupy the same orbital.



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
According to Hund's Rule, electrons fill orbitals of the same sublevel singly and with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimizes electron-electron repulsion and leads to a more stable, lower-energy configuration. Statement I is correct.
Electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins, not parallel spins, to satisfy the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which prevents two electrons in the same orbital from having identical properties. Statement II is incorrect.
Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows them to share an orbital, as long as their spins are opposite ($\uparrow$ and $\downarrow$). This difference in spin enables two electrons to occupy the same spatial region without violating exclusion rules. Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
Which energy transition in the hydrogen emission spectrum has the highest frequency?


- A.$\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 1$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Below is the energy level diagram of hydrogen.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59852886-12f9-4f0c-bdd6-5e47eba81474/images/4de51eb8-2a0c-4b0e-a1ee-a2a3a35a8b38/CH1154.png)


[© Revision Village 2023]
Based on the equation $E=hf$, the greater the energy of the emission, the greater the frequency of the emission. The four transitions are shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59852886-12f9-4f0c-bdd6-5e47eba81474/images/7c0c049f-08ed-4e79-9e02-d3174160b738/CH1154B.png)


[© Revision Village 2023]
Transition D is the one with the greatest energy emission and the one with the greatest frequency.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall the energy level diagram of hydrogen and compare different emissions.

list.title: Question 49
list.content:
Which of the following correctly describes the electron configuration of the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion?


- Number of occupied $p$ sublevelsNumber of occupied $p$ orbitalsA.$\hspace{1em}$26B.212C.62D.122
list.markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion, the electron configuration is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6.$ This means that two $p$ sublevels are occupied: $2p$ and $3p.$ Each of these sublevels includes three $p$ orbitals, and in this case, all six $p$ orbitals are fully occupied. Understanding the distinction between sublevels and orbitals is essential to interpreting electron configurations accurately.

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).
Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy ($E \propto f$). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy is $n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)


This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
Which electron transition in a hydrogen atom emits the longest wavelength of light?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n = 3$ to $n = 2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n = 4$ to $n = 3$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n = 5$ to $n = 4$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n = 2$ to $n = 1$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The electronic energy levels for the hydrogen atom converge at high energy (furthest from the nucleus), where $n = 1$ is closest to the nucleus. A simple diagram can be drawn to show the relative energy levels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e38802a0-9d42-4913-b9b7-de2c97c3a807/images/a330f257-07c0-49ca-84ff-4a03ecd5af38/CH2032.png)


Each transition is indicated with an arrow, where the longest arrow equates to the highest energy. Energy and the wavelength of light are inversely proportional as follows:
$E = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}$
Therefore, a higher energy has a lower wavelength (and vice versa). For this question, we are looking for the shortest arrow which is the lowest energy and the longest wavelength (so, $n= 5$ to $n = 4).$
